... ah!  the technology was developed in 1849, and your collection assembled in the "late nineteenth century"; that narrows it!

comment.author: 36548643@N02
comment._content:
As Aaron has mentioned 'when was this photograph taken?'
I love the pics but surely a museum site should be more specific about the date?

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: Hi Aaron and *veriditas* Unfortunately, we don't have dates for many of the lantern slides. The collection came from various sources and over a period of time. We only have the slides to go by for dates and many of them don't have dates on them. If there are dates, they are included in the captions. We can only provide a general date range based on when the collection was created. The collection was started in the late 19th century and into the early 20th century. You can read more about the collection history here. -Angie Park, Brooklyn Museum Archives

comment.author: 33177139@N06
comment._content: super sharp imaging really helps to identify symbols or hieroglyphs for those armchair archaeologists like myself....excellent transfer work..

comment.author: 64086917@N00
comment._content: Isn't this the Khonsu temple of Karnak?

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:
Hi wjgmspeedy,
Good eye. I checked with our curators who responded: 

"This is indeed the Karnak precinct, where the temple of Khonsu is a subordinate structure," and offered this more detailed caption:

View of the Karnak temple precinct, gate of Ptolemy III, with the temple of Khonsu in the background. 

Thanks for your input,
Deb Wythe, Brooklyn Museum Digital Lab
